Abstract: Elastic thermobarometry represents a cutting-edge approach in the study of metamorphic processes, offering a novel lens through which to decipher the pressure-temperature (P-T) histories of rocks. This technique leverages the elastic properties of minerals, which are sensitive to changes in P-T conditions, to infer the metamorphic paths experienced by geological materials. By integrating Raman spectroscopy with advanced modeling of elastic, viscous, and plastic behaviors, researchers can now more accurately reconstruct the P-T trajectories of metamorphic rocks. This method provides a significant advancement over traditional thermobarometric techniques, as it accounts for the complex interplay between mineral elasticity and the dynamic conditions of metamorphism. The application of elastic thermobarometry has the potential to revolutionize our understanding of metamorphic processes, offering insights into the thermal and mechanical evolution of the Earth's crust with unprecedented precision.
